thread.title: It's July, and they still don't know when Bertha will tunnel again
thread.title_full: It's July, and they still don't know when Bertha will tunnel again

author: Sarah Aitchison
title: It's July, and they still don't know when Bertha will tunnel again
text:
It's July, and they still don't know when Bertha will tunnel again Jul 2, 2015, 12:47pm PDT Updated Washington State Department of Transportation Seattle Tunnel Partners crews inspect the installation of Bertha's new inner seal ring;… more There's still no timeline for the tunnel. Seattle Tunnel Partners, the joint venture contractor to dig a highway tunnel to replace the Alaskan Way Viaduct, said in May it would produce a new estimated completion date by the end of June. That self-made deadline has passed. Related Content See All Homes of the Day The state Department of Transportation expects to get an updated schedule from the contractors in the next two weeks. The $3.1-billion project is already more than two years delayed because the giant tunnel-boring machine, nicknamed Bertha, broke down in December 2013. Built by Hitachi Zosen of Japan, Bertha had to be shut down a little more than 1,000 feet into its 1.7-mile underground journey. Hitachi Zosen sent redesigned replacement parts from Japan and crews are working to install them and get the machine up and running again. Seattle Tunnel Partners crews had to dig a 120-foot-deep pit and lift the cutter head to the surface. It's been under repair since April. When repairs started, crews were hoping to have Bertha tunneling again in August. The Legislature eliminated the project’s independent oversight panel last month because of concerns that participation might increase the state's liability for cost overruns. Under the design-build contract with Seattle Tunnel Partners, many of the risks and decisions are the responsibilty of the contractor.
